sn2.30:0.3.eng: The Disciples of Various Monastics of Other Religions

sn2.30:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn2.30:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn2.30:1.3.pli: Atha kho sambahulā nānātitthiyasāvakā devaputtā asamo ca sahali ca nīko ca ākoṭako ca vegabbhari ca māṇavagāmiyo ca abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ veḷuvanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu.
sn2.30:1.3.eng: Then, late at night, several glorious godlings lit up the entire Bamboo Grove. They were Asama, Sahalī, Niṅka, Ākoṭaka, Veṭambarī, and Māṇavagāmiya, and all of them were disciples of various monastics of other religions. They went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side.
sn2.30:1.3.comm: Most of these individuals are unknown elsewhere. | For detailed presentations of the sectarian teachings that follow, see DN 2.

sn2.30:1.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho asamo devaputto pūraṇaṃ kassapaṃ ārabbha bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn2.30:1.4.eng: Standing to one side, the godling Asama spoke this verse about Pūraṇa Kassapa in the Buddha’s presence:

sn2.30:2.5.eng: What he taught should truly be trusted,

sn2.30:2.6.eng: he’s worthy of esteem as Teacher.”
sn2.30:2.6.comm: This is regarded as a pernicious wrong view, which results in rebirth in hell. This shows the complexity of kamma, as Asama must have done some other good kamma to be reborn as a godling.

sn2.30:3.1.pli: Atha kho sahali devaputto makkhaliṃ gosālaṃ ārabbha bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn2.30:3.1.eng: Then the godling Sahalī spoke this verse about the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla in the Buddha’s presence:
sn2.30:3.1.comm: A group of gods of this name (meaning “with plough”?) appeared alongside Vishnu at DN 20:14.1.

sn2.30:4.1.eng: “Through fervent mortification in disgust of sin he became well restrained.

sn2.30:4.2.eng: He gave up quarreling with people.

sn2.30:4.3.eng: Refraining from false speech, he spoke the truth.

sn2.30:4.4.pli: Na hi nūna tādisaṃ karoti pāpan”ti.
sn2.30:4.4.eng: Surely such a man does no wrong!”

sn2.30:5.1.pli: Atha kho nīko devaputto nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ ārabbha bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn2.30:5.1.eng: Then the godling Niṅka spoke this verse about the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan in the Buddha’s presence:

sn2.30:6.2.eng: well restrained in the fourfold constraint;
sn2.30:6.2.comm: For this Jain teaching see DN 2:29.4, DN 25:16.3

sn2.30:6.3.eng: explaining what is seen and heard:

sn2.30:6.4.eng: surely he can be no sinner!”

sn2.30:7.1.pli: Atha kho ākoṭako devaputto nānātitthiye ārabbha bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn2.30:7.1.eng: Then the godling Ākoṭaka spoke this verse about various sectarian teachers in the Buddha’s presence:

sn2.30:8.1.comm: Pakudhaka Kātiyāna is a variant spelling of Pakudha Kaccāyana.

sn2.30:8.2.eng: as well as this bamboo-staffed ascetic and Pūraṇa:

sn2.30:8.4.pli: Na hi nūna te sappurisehi dūre”ti.
sn2.30:8.4.eng: surely they weren’t far from truly good men!”

sn2.30:9.1.pli: Atha kho vegabbhari devaputto ākoṭakaṃ devaputtaṃ gāthāya paccabhāsi:
sn2.30:9.1.eng: Then the godling Veṭambarī replied to the godling Ākoṭaka in verse:

sn2.30:10.3.eng: A nude liar with suspicious conduct,

sn2.30:10.4.eng: though they teach a community, is not like the good.”

sn2.30:11.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā begabbhariṃ devaputtaṃ anvāvisitvā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn2.30:11.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked took possession of the godling Veṭambarī and spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn2.30:12.1.eng: “Those dedicated to mortification in disgust of sin,

sn2.30:12.4.eng: they rejoice in the heavenly realm.

sn2.30:12.5.eng: Indeed, those mortals give correct instructions

sn2.30:13.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā “māro ayaṃ pāpimā” iti viditvā, māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāya paccabhāsi:
sn2.30:13.1.eng: Then the Buddha, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:

sn2.30:14.1.pli: “Ye keci rūpā idha vā huraṃ vā,
sn2.30:14.1.eng: “Whatever forms there are in this life or the next,

sn2.30:14.2.eng: and those of shining beauty in the sky,

sn2.30:14.3.eng: all of these you praise, Namuci,

sn2.30:14.4.eng: like bait tossed out for catching fish.”

sn2.30:15.1.pli: Atha kho māṇavagāmiyo devaputto bhagavantaṃ ārabbha bhagavato santike imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn2.30:15.1.eng: Then the godling Māṇavagāmiya spoke this verse about the Buddha in his presence:
sn2.30:15.1.comm: The celebration of Namuci’s defeat by Māṇavagāmiya is a striking verbal allusion to Rig Veda 5.30.7c, where the defeat of Namuci opened the way for “the progress of Manu” (manave gātum, Rig Veda 5.30.7c), i.e. the spread of the Aryan peoples who were Manu’s children. Reading Pali gāmiya as a secondary derivation from gama, “going”, yields the sense, “The Progress of Manu’s Children”. Here the term can have the Buddhist sense of the path of the Aryans.

sn2.30:16.2.eng: Vipula’s said to be the best.

sn2.30:16.3.eng: Seta is the best of the Himalayan peaks,

sn2.30:16.4.eng: and the sun, of travelers in space.

sn2.30:17.1.eng: The ocean is the best of seas,

sn2.30:17.2.eng: and the moon, of lights that shine at night.

sn2.30:17.3.eng: But in all the world with its gods,

sn2.30:18.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on Godlings are complete.

sn2.4:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho māgadho devaputto bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn2.4:1.2.eng: Standing to one side, the godling Maghada addressed the Buddha in verse:
sn2.4:1.2.comm: The name is variously spelled māgha (like the previous Sutta) or māgadha, suggesting he is the god “of Magadha”—but we meet no such deity elsewhere. I think it should be corrected to Maghada, “giver of bounty”, cf. Rig Vedic maghadeya (7.67.9), indro maghāni dayate (7.21.7). I adopt this spelling even though it is, so far as I know, unattested in manuscripts. See also note on next Sutta.

sn2.4:2.3.eng: We’ve come to ask the Buddha;

sn2.4:2.4.eng: how are we to understand this?”

sn2.4:3.1.eng: “There are four lamps in the world,

sn2.4:4.3.eng: But a Buddha is the best of blazes:

sn2.5:1.2.pli: Atha kho dāmali devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn2.5:1.2.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious godling Dāmali, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side,
sn2.5:1.2.comm: Dāmali is elsewhere unknown. But cf. Vedic dāman, “giver”, which is associated with magha at Rig Veda 5.79.4. Given its close association with Indra, who is “made to be a giver” (8.93.8, see too 5.36.1, 6.24.4), it seems likely this is yet another epithet of Sakka.

sn2.5:1.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho dāmali devaputto bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn2.5:1.3.eng: and spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn2.5:2.1.eng: “This is what should be done by a brahmin:
sn2.5:2.1.comm: Dāmali is treating the “brahmin” as one who still needs to practice. | This line parallels the opening of the Mettasutta (Snp 1.8:1.1).

sn2.5:2.3.eng: Then, with the giving up of sensual pleasures,

sn2.5:2.4.eng: they won’t hope to be reborn.”

sn2.5:3.1.eng: “The brahmin has nothing left to do,”
sn2.5:3.1.comm: For the Buddha, the only true brahmin is the arahant.

sn2.5:3.4.eng: So long as a personage fails to gain a footing in the river,

sn2.5:3.5.comm: This couplet confirms the meaning “swim” for āyūhati.

sn2.5:3.6.eng: But someone who has gained a footing <j>and stands on dry land

sn2.5:3.7.eng: need not swim, <j>for they have reached the far shore.

sn2.5:4.1.eng: Dāmali, this is a simile for the brahmin,

sn2.5:4.2.eng: alert, a meditator who has ended defilements.

sn2.5:4.3.eng: Since they’ve reached the end of rebirth and death,

sn2.5:4.4.eng: they need not swim, <j>for they have reached the far shore.”

sn2.6:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho kāmado devaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn2.6:1.2.eng: Standing to one side, the godling Kāmada said to the Buddha,
sn2.6:1.2.comm: Kāmada, the “granter of pleasure” is otherwise unknown in early texts, but later is an epithet of the Sun or of Shiva. More likely, given that kāmada has the same sense as the names in the previous Suttas, it is once more Indra under another name.

sn2.6:1.3.eng: “It’s too hard, Blessed One! It’s just too hard!”

sn2.6:2.1.eng: “They do it even though it’s hard,”

sn2.6:2.3.eng: “the stable trainees with ethics, and immersion.

sn2.6:2.4.eng: For one who has entered the homeless life,

sn2.6:3.1.eng: “Such contentment, Blessed One, is hard to find.”

sn2.6:4.1.eng: “They find it even though it’s hard,”

sn2.6:5.1.eng: “But it’s hard, Blessed One, to immerse this mind in samādhi.”

sn2.6:6.1.eng: “They become immersed in samādhi <j>even though it’s hard,”

sn2.6:6.4.eng: Having cut through the net of Death,

sn2.6:6.5.eng: the noble ones, Kāmada, go on their way.”

sn2.6:7.1.eng: “But this path, Blessed One, is rough and hard to travel.”

sn2.6:8.2.eng: the noble ones, Kāmada, go on their way.

sn2.6:8.5.eng: But the path of the noble ones is smooth,

sn2.6:8.6.eng: for the noble ones are smooth amid the rough.”

sn2.7:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho pañcālacaṇḍo devaputto bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn2.7:1.2.eng: Standing to one side, the godling Pañcālacaṇḍa spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:
sn2.7:1.2.comm: This saying by Pañcālacaṇḍa is quoted by Udāyī and explained by Ānanda at AN 9.42. Pañcālacaṇḍa appears alongside Āḷavaka, the tutelary deity of Āḷavī, hinting that he may be the fierce (caṇḍa) protector of the Pañcāla clan (DN 32:10.16). Several Pañcālacaṇḍas appear in the Jātakas: a licentious youth and a misogynistic chaplain (Ja 536), and a prince of Pañcāla (Ja 546). A Pañcālacaṇḍa appears as a Vedic teacher of the idea that speech is what unifies (Aitereya Āraṇyaka 3.1.6 = Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka 7.19, Gopatha Brāhmaṇa 1.1.27n). None of these, however, have any obvious relation to our text.

sn2.7:2.2.eng: was discovered by the Buddha of vast intelligence,

sn2.7:2.3.comm: The compound jhānamabujjhi can be resolved as either jhānaṁ abujjhi (“awakened to absorption”) or jhānena abujjhi (“awakened by means of absorption”). At AN 9.42, Ānanda explains that each stage of absorption is an “opening” relative to what came before, but still a “confinement”, and only Nibbāna is the opening without confinement. The thrust of the verse, therefore, is the Buddha’s insight into the nature of absorption, supporting the sense “awakened to absorption”.

sn2.7:2.4.eng: the sage, the solitary boss bull.”

sn2.8:1.2.pli: Atha kho tāyano devaputto purāṇatitthakaro abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn2.8:1.2.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious godling Tāyana, formerly a religious founder, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side,
sn2.8:1.2.comm: Tāyana means “defender” (here the affix -ana is agentive). Compare Vedic trātṛ, “defender”, an epithet of Indra (eg. Rig Veda 2.23.8, 6.25.7).

sn2.8:1.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho tāyano devaputto bhagavato santike imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn2.8:1.3.eng: and recited these verses in the Buddha’s presence:

sn2.8:2.1.comm: These verses are often recited by mendicants to remind them of their commitment.

sn2.8:2.3.eng: A sage who doesn’t give up sensual pleasures

sn2.8:2.4.eng: is not reborn in a unified state.
sn2.8:2.4.comm: As, for example, the gods of universal beauty (AN 7.44:4.1). Tāyana taught rebirth in the Brahmā realm as the goal of his spiritual life, as did other religious founders of the past (AN 6.54, AN 7.73, AN 7.74, AN 7.66).

sn2.8:3.1.eng: If one is to do what should be done,

sn2.8:3.3.eng: For the life gone forth when laxly led

sn2.8:3.4.eng: just stirs up dust all the more.

sn2.8:4.1.eng: A bad deed is better left undone,

sn2.8:4.2.eng: for it will plague you later on.

sn2.8:4.3.eng: A good deed is better done,

sn2.8:4.4.eng: one that does not plague you.

sn2.8:5.1.eng: When kusa grass is wrongly grasped

sn2.8:5.3.eng: So too, the ascetic life, when wrongly taken,

sn2.8:7.1.eng: That’s what the godling Tāyana said.

sn2.8:7.2.pli: idaṃ vatvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn2.8:7.2.eng: Then he bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right side, before vanishing right there.

sn2.8:8.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassā rattiyā accayena bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn2.8:8.1.eng: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha told the mendicants all that had happened.

sn2.8:8.2.pli: “imaṃ, bhikkhave, rattiṃ tāyano nāma devaputto purāṇatitthakaro abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn2.8:8.2.eng: “Mendicants, tonight, the glorious godling Tāyana, formerly a religious founder, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, came to me, bowed, stood to one side,

sn2.8:8.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho, bhikkhave, tāyano devaputto mama santike imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn2.8:8.3.eng: and recited these verses in my presence.” The Buddha repeated the verses in full, adding:

sn2.8:14.1.pli: Idamavoca, bhikkhave, tāyano devaputto, idaṃ vatvā maṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyi.
sn2.8:14.1.eng: “That’s what the godling Tāyana said. Then he bowed and respectfully circled me, keeping me on his right side, before vanishing right there.

sn2.8:14.2.eng: Mendicants, learn the verses of Tāyana!

sn2.8:14.5.eng: These verses are beneficial and relate to the fundamentals of the spiritual life.”

sn2.9:1.1.comm: This discourse and the next provide the Buddhist community with verses to recite for solace on the terrifying occasion of an eclipse.

sn2.9:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena candimā devaputto rāhunā asurindena gahito hoti.
sn2.9:1.2.eng: Now at that time the Moon God had been seized by Rāhu, lord of titans.
sn2.9:1.2.comm: Rāhu (“seizer”), is able to swallow the Moon and Sun because he has largest physical body of any creature (AN 4.15:2.1). This also lets him divert the rains (AN 5.197:3.1). This myth is alluded to in Atharvaveda 19.9.10a and Chāndogya Upaniṣad 8.13.1. An eclipse was a day unfit for study (Manu 4.110). The full story of Rāhu, however, is not told until the Purāṇas, so this Sutta is possibly the oldest telling that survives.

sn2.9:1.3.pli: Atha kho candimā devaputto bhagavantaṃ anussaramāno tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn2.9:1.3.eng: Then the Moon God, recollecting the Buddha, at that time spoke this verse:
sn2.9:1.3.comm: Candimā, the “moon” as celestial body or deity, appears frequently in the Vedas (eg. Rig Veda 1.24.10, 1.102.2, etc.). A slightly different form of this name appears in SN 2.11.

sn2.9:2.3.comm: The later Purāṇic legend says that Rāhu disguised himself as a brahmin to drink the gods’ nectar of immortality. But he was spied by the Sun and Moon, decapitated by Vishnu, and now his disembodied head traverses the skies as a black planet. He does not forget how the Sun and Moon betrayed him, so, nursing his enmity, he swallows them when he can. He is ever frustrated as they simply pass out through his throat.

sn2.9:2.4.comm: Here the sense of “refuge” (saraṇa) is both physical and spiritual.

sn2.9:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā candimaṃ devaputtaṃ ārabbha rāhuṃ asurindaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn2.9:3.1.eng: Then the Buddha addressed Rāhu in verse concerning the Moon God:

sn2.9:4.1.eng: “The Moon God has gone for refuge

sn2.9:4.2.eng: to the Realized One, the perfected one.

sn2.9:4.3.eng: The Buddhas have compassion for the world—

sn2.9:5.1.pli: Atha kho rāhu asurindo candimaṃ devaputtaṃ muñcitvā taramānarūpo yena vepacitti asurindo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā saṃviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn2.9:5.1.eng: Then Rāhu, having released the Moon, rushed to see Vepacitti, lord of titans and stood to one side, shocked and awestruck.
sn2.9:5.1.comm: Rāhu was the son of Vepacitti and, according to Purāṇic legend, Siṁhikā.

sn2.9:5.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitaṃ kho rāhuṃ asurindaṃ vepacitti asurindo gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:

sn2.9:6.3.eng: and came here looking like you’re in shock:

sn2.9:6.4.eng: why do you stand there so scared?”

sn2.9:7.1.eng: “My head would have exploded in seven pieces,

sn2.9:7.2.eng: I would have found no happiness in life,

sn2.9:7.3.eng: if, when enchanted by the Buddha’s verse,
sn2.9:7.3.comm: Abhigīta first appears with regards to a drop of Soma that has been “chanted over”, “besung”, or “enchanted” and hence imbued with potency (Rig Veda 9.96.23). Throughout Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 8.5.4 it is used more prosaically: a history of horse sacrifices is listed, each event honored with a specific verse “sung about” it. In Pali, the phrase gāthābhigīta is found only in this passage and when the Buddha refused to eat food “chanted over” by a brahmins (eg. SN 7.8:8.1). In both cases the chanting has a mysterious potency, so I render “enchanted with verse”.

sn2.9:7.4.eng: I had not released the Moon.”
